title: Time-varying Mediation Analysis with Binary Exposure and Single Mediator
text: First example mediator precedes time-varying confounders (M→LM \rightarrow L). corresponds following DAG DAG context mediator precedes time-varying confounders specify causal ordering M→LM \rightarrow L, set argument tvar_to_med = FALSE (default). contrast, time-varying confounder assumed precede mediator (L→ML \rightarrow M), use tvar_to_med = TRUE. current version tvmedg supports lag-based functional forms variable histories. example, specify 2 lags. default, logistic regression used binary variables, linear regression used continuous variables. continuous variables time indices, spline-based models can used specifying: sp_list, sp_type, sp_df. example sets cubic spline 3 degrees freedom month variable mm. Additional variables, spline types (e.g., “ns”), df can added arguments model nonlinear effects. Lastly, run algorithm using 1000 Monte Carlo samples.
code: library(doParallel) #> Loading required package: foreach #> Loading required package: iterators #> Loading required package: parallel  cl <- makeCluster(2) registerDoParallel(cl) med_MtoL <- tvmedg(data = sim_data,                    id = "id",                    basec = c("age","sex","ow","risk"),                    expo = c("Ap"),                    med = c("Mp"),                    tvar = c("L1","L2","L3"),                    outc = c("Yp"),                    time = c("mm"),                    lag = 2,                    tvar_to_med = F,                    cont_exp = F,                    mreg = "binomial",                    lreg = c("binomial","gaussian","gaussian"),                    yreg = "binomial",                    sp_list = c("mm"),                    sp_type = c("bs"),                    sp_df = c(3),                    followup = 12,                    seed = 123,                    montecarlo = 1000,                    boot = F,                    parallel = TRUE) #> Q(a,a): 0.23  #> Q(a,a*): 0.045  #> Q(a*,a*): 0.01  #> Indirect (rIE): 0.185  #> Direct (rDE): 0.035  #> Total (rTE): 0.22  #> Proportional explain: 0.841  #> Total time elapsed: 6.367038 mins stopCluster(cl)

title: Time-varying Mediation Analysis with Binary Exposure and Single Mediator
text: tvmedg implements non-parametric bootstrap obtain confidence intervals effect estimates. can enabled setting boot = TRUE, along specifying number bootstrap samples via nboot, desired confidence level ci (e.g., ci = 0.95). illustration purposes, reduce computational burden example, run 5 bootstrap iterations.
code: cl <- makeCluster(2) registerDoParallel(cl)  med_MtoL_ci <- tvmedg(data = sim_data,                       id = "id",                       basec = c("age","sex","ow","risk"),                       expo = c("Ap"),                       med = c("Mp"),                       tvar = c("L1","L2","L3"),                       outc = c("Yp"),                       time = c("mm"),                       lag = 2,                       tvar_to_med = F,                       cont_exp = F,                       mreg = "binomial",                       lreg = c("binomial","gaussian","gaussian"),                       yreg = "binomial",                       sp_list = c("mm"),                       sp_type = c("bs"),                       sp_df = c(3),                       followup = 12,                       seed = 123,                       montecarlo = 1000,                       boot = T,                       nboot = 5,                       ci = .95,                      parallel = TRUE) #> Q(a,a): 0.815 (0, 0.921)  #> Q(a,a*): 0.791 (0, 0.906)  #> Q(a*,a*): 0 (0, 0.27)  #> Indirect (rIE): 0.024 (-0.015, 0.138)  #> Direct (rDE): 0.791 (-0.267, 0.905)  #> Total (rTE): 0.815 (-0.206, 0.92)  #> Proportional explain: 0.029 (-0.293, 0.694)  #> Total time elapsed: 32.26849 mins stopCluster(cl)

title: Time-varying Mediation Analysis with Binary Exposure and Single Mediator
text: Diagnostic tools checking g-computation algorithm limited. However, expect observed outcome trajectory lie predicted values Q(,)Q(, ), Q(,*)Q(, ^*), Q(*,*)Q(^*, ^*) time. aid evaluation, tvmedg provides two diagnostic plots: plot comparing observed outcome simulated outcomes three exposure–mediator scenarios across time. plot cumulative outcomes time scenario. Time-varying plot  Cumulative plot
code: plot(med_MtoL, "tvY") plot(med_MtoL, "cumY")

title: G-computation Algorithms in tvmedg
text: Notations Let AA denote exposure interest, taking values aa *^\ast. Let YY outcome, MM mediator, LL time-varying confounder, vv vector pre-exposure (time-fixed) covariates. Let YaY_a MaM_a denote values outcome mediator, respectively, observed exposure AA set aa; similarly, Ya*Y_{^\ast} Ma*M_{^\ast} represent potential values =*= ^\ast. average total effect can decomposed natural direct indirect effects : E(Ya−Ya*)=E(YaMa−Ya*Ma*)=E(YaMa−YaMa*)⏟Natural indirect effect+E(YaMa*−Ya*Ma*)⏟Natural direct effect E(Y_a - Y_{^*}) = E(Y_{aM_{}} - Y_{^*M_{^*}}) =  \underbrace{E(Y_{aM_{}} - Y_{aM_{^*}})}_{\text{Natural indirect effect}} + \underbrace{E(Y_{aM_{^*}} - Y_{^*M_{^*}})}_{\text{Natural direct effect}} potential outcomes YaMaY_{aM_a} Ya*Ma*Y_{^\ast M_{^\ast}} represent values outcome exposure levels aa *^\ast, respectively, mediator taking natural value exposure. contrast, YaMa*Y_{aM_{^\ast}} describes outcome exposure aa, mediator set value taken *^\ast, capturing cross-world scenario relevant mediation analysis. context mediator–outcome confounders affected exposure (.e., $Y_{} \\!\perp\!\!\!\perp M_{^*}|V$ - violation identification condition), natural direct indirect effect identified. randomized interventional analogues introduced. Let Ga|vG_{|v} denote random draw distribution mediator exposure AA set aa conditional covariates vv. words, GG reflects stochastic draw conditional distribution rather fixed potential value mediator. randomized interventional analogues natural direct indirect effects defined E(YaGa∣v)−E(Ya*Ga*∣v)=E(YaGa∣v)−E(YaGa*∣v)+E(YaGa*∣v)−E(Ya*Ga*∣v) E(Y_{aG_{} \mid v}) - E(Y_{^*G_{^*} \mid v})  = E(Y_{aG_{} \mid v}) - E(Y_{aG_{^*} \mid v})  +  E(Y_{aG_{^*} \mid v}) - E(Y_{^*G_{^*} \mid v}) longitudinal setting, overbars denote history variables time tt. total effect longitudinal exposure regime ‾\bar{} versus ‾*\bar{}^* can decomposed : E(Ya‾G‾‾∣v∣v)−E(Ya‾*G‾‾*∣v∣v)=E(Ya‾G‾‾∣v∣v)−E(Ya‾G‾‾*∣v∣v)⏟interventional indirect effect+E(Ya‾G‾‾*∣v∣v)−E(Ya‾*G‾‾*∣v∣v)⏟interventional direct effect. E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{} \mid v}} \mid v) - E(Y_{\bar{}^* \bar{G}_{\bar{}^* \mid v}} \mid v) =   \underbrace{E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{} \mid v}} \mid v) - E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{}^* \mid v}} \mid v)}_{\text{interventional indirect effect}} +  \underbrace{E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{}^* \mid v}} \mid v) - E(Y_{\bar{}^* \bar{G}_{\bar{}^* \mid v}} \mid v)}_{\text{interventional direct effect}}. shown VanderWeele Tchetgen Tchetgen (2017), interventional analogues natural direct indirect effects, causal DAG () mediator precedes time-varying confounder (MM preceding LL), can identified using -called mediational g-formula. DAG context mediator precedes time-varying confounder particular, identification E(Ya‾G‾‾*∣v∣v)E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{}^*}\mid v} \mid v) E(Ya‾G‾‾*∣v∣v)=∫m‾∫l‾(T−1)E(Y∣‾,m‾,l‾,v)∏t=1T−1dP(l‾(t)∣‾(t),m‾(t),l‾(t−1),v)×[∫l‾†(T−1)∏t=1TP(m(t)∣‾*(t),m‾(t−1),l‾†(t−1),v)dP(l‾†(t−1)∣‾*(t−1),m‾(t−1),l‾†(t−2),v)]\begin{align*} E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{}^*}\mid v} \mid v) = &\int_{\bar{m}} \int_{\bar{l}(T-1)} E(Y \mid \bar{}, \bar{m}, \bar{l}, v) \prod_{t=1}^{T-1} dP\left( \bar{l}(t) \mid \bar{}(t), \bar{m}(t), \bar{l}(t-1), v \right) \\ &\times \left[ \int_{\bar{l}^\dagger(T-1)} \prod_{t=1}^{T} P\left( m(t) \mid \bar{}^*(t), \bar{m}(t-1), \bar{l}^\dagger(t-1), v \right) \, dP\left( \bar{l}^\dagger(t-1) \mid \bar{}^*(t-1), \bar{m}(t-1), \bar{l}^\dagger(t-2), v \right) \right] \end{align*} context time-varying confounder precedes mediator (LL preceding MM) DAG context time-varying confounder precedes mediator mediational g-formula identification E(Ya‾G‾‾*∣v∣v)E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{}^*}\mid v} \mid v) becomes E(Ya‾G‾‾*∣v∣v)=∫m‾∫l‾(T−1)E(Y∣‾,m‾,l‾,v)∏t=1T−1dP(l‾(t)∣‾(t),m‾(t−1),l‾(t−1),v)×d[∫l‾†(T−1)∏t=1TP(m(t)∣‾*(t),m‾(t−1),l‾†(t),v)dP(l‾†(t)∣‾*(t),m‾(t−1),l‾†(t−1),v)].\begin{align*} E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{}^*}\mid v} \mid v) = &\int_{\bar{m}} \int_{\bar{l}(T-1)} E(Y \mid \bar{}, \bar{m}, \bar{l}, v) \prod_{t=1}^{T-1} dP\left( \bar{l}(t) \mid \bar{}(t), \bar{m}(t-1), \bar{l}(t-1), v \right) \\ &\times d\left[ \int_{\bar{l}^\dagger(T-1)} \prod_{t=1}^{T} P\left( m(t) \mid \bar{}^*(t), \bar{m}(t-1), \bar{l}^\dagger(t), v \right) \, dP\left( \bar{l}^\dagger(t) \mid \bar{}^*(t), \bar{m}(t-1), \bar{l}^\dagger(t-1), v \right) \right]. \end{align*} ease notation, let’s adopt shorthand notations VanderWeele Tchetgen Tchetgen (2017) paper: Q(,)Q(, ) represent E(Ya‾G‾‾∣v∣v)E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{}}\mid v} \mid v), Q(,*)Q(, ^*) E(Ya‾G‾‾*∣v∣v)E(Y_{\bar{} \bar{G}_{\bar{}^*}\mid v} \mid v), Q(*,*)Q(^*, ^*) E(Ya‾*G‾‾*∣v∣v)E(Y_{\bar{}^* \bar{G}_{\bar{}^*}\mid v} \mid v),

title: G-computation Algorithms in tvmedg
text: tvmedg implements g-computation estimate interventional direct indirect effects longitudinal settings, based mediational g-formula mentioned . core algorithm involves 4 main steps: Step 1: Fitting parametric models tvmedg() fits user-specified regression models time-varying variable, conditional relevant history baseline covariates: E(L‾(t)∣‾(t),m‾(t),l‾(t−1),v)E(\bar{L}(t) \mid \bar{}(t), \bar{m}(t), \bar{l}(t-1), v) (MM preceding LL) E(L‾(t)∣‾(t),m‾(t−1),l‾(t−1),v)E(\bar{L}(t) \mid \bar{}(t), \bar{m}(t-1), \bar{l}(t-1), v) (LL preceding MM) E(M(t)∣‾*(t),m‾(t−1),l‾†(t−1),v)E(M(t) \mid \bar{}^*(t), \bar{m}(t-1), \bar{l}^\dagger(t-1), v) E(Y∣‾,m‾,l‾,v)E(Y \mid \bar{}, \bar{m}, \bar{l}, v) Step 2: Monte Carlo sampling Resample values variables baseline, including time-fixed covariates VV time-varying confounders LL time t=0t = 0. step approximates baseline covariate distribution improves stability precision predictions Step 3. Step 3: Predict follow-Using baseline samples generated Step 2, Step 3 simulates follow-trajectories sequentially predicting time-varying confounders, mediators, outcomes specified exposure regimes. process illustrated following figure (example estimating Q(,*)Q(, ^*)) context binary outcome. g-computation tvmedg Step 4: Estimating interventional analogues natural direct indirect effects Estimating Q(,)Q(, ), Q(,*)Q(, ^*), Q(*,*)Q(^*, ^*) end follow-derive: Interventional total effect (rTE): Q(,)−Q(*,*)Q(, ) - Q(^*, ^*) Interventional direct effect (rDE): Q(,*)−Q(*,*)Q(, ^*) - Q(^*, ^*) Interventional indirect effect: Q(,)−Q(,*)Q(, ) - Q(, ^*) Proportional explain: Indirect effect / Total effect

title: G-computation Algorithms in tvmedg
text: VanderWeele, T. (2015). Explanation causal inference: methods mediation interaction. Oxford University Press. VanderWeele, T. J., & Tchetgen Tchetgen, E. J. (2017). Mediation analysis time varying exposures mediators. Journal Royal Statistical Society Series B: Statistical Methodology, 79(3), 917-938.

code: @Manual{,   title = {tvmedg: Time-varying mediation analysis using g-computation},   author = {Quynh Long Khuong and Nguyen {Pham Nguyen The} and Thinh Ong and Kelly D. Getz},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://causalepi.github.io/tvmedg/}, }

title: Time-varying mediation analysis using g-computation
text: tvmedg package implements causal mediation analysis using g-computation longitudinal settings time-varying exposure, mediators, confounders. extends g-computation framework decompose total effects randomized interventional analogues natural direct indirect effects, presence time-varying confounding affected prior exposures mediators. approach builds upon ‘mediational g-formula’ introduced VanderWeele Tchetgen Tchetgen (2017). current version tvmedg supports multiple mediators, binary continuous exposures, spline-based functional forms continuous variables. package also enables parallel computing efficiency large-scale analyses. Besides core modeling functions, tvmedg includes functions visualizing diagnosing model results.

title: Time-varying mediation analysis using g-computation
text: development version tvmedg can installed GitHub:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("causalepi/tvmedg")

title: Time-varying mediation analysis using g-computation
code: library(tvmedg) library(doParallel) #> Loading required package: foreach #> Loading required package: iterators #> Loading required package: parallel

title: Time-varying mediation analysis using g-computation
code: cl <- makeCluster(8) registerDoParallel(cl)  op <- tvmedg(data = sim_data,        id = "id",        basec = c("age","sex","ow","risk"),        expo = c("Ap"),        med = c("Mp"),        tvar = c("L1","L2","L3"),        outc = c("Yp"),        time = c("mm"),        lag = 2,        cont_exp = F,        mreg = "binomial",        lreg = c("binomial","gaussian","gaussian"),        yreg = "binomial",        sp_list = c("mm"),        sp_type = c("bs"),        sp_df = c(3),        followup = 12,        seed = 123,        montecarlo = 1000,        boot = F,        parallel = TRUE) #> Q(a,a): 0.188  #> Q(a,a*): 0.037  #> Q(a*,a*): 0.008  #> Indirect (rIE): 0.151  #> Direct (rDE): 0.029  #> Total (rTE): 0.18  #> Proportional explain: 0.839  #> Total time elapsed: 5.774524 mins  stopCluster(cl)
